review.title: A Framework for Knowledge Management and Automated Reasoning Applied on Intelligent Transport Systems
review.abstract: Cyber-Physical Systems in general, and Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS) in particular use heterogeneous data sources combined with problem solving expertise in order to make critical decisions that may lead to some form of actions e.g., driver notifications, change of traffic light signals and braking to prevent an accident. Currently, a major part of the decision process is done by human domain experts, which is time-consuming, tedious and error-prone. Additionally, due to the intrinsic nature of knowledge possession this decision process cannot be easily replicated or reused. Therefore, there is a need for automating the reasoning processes by providing computational systems a formal representation of the domain knowledge and a set of methods to process that knowledge. In this paper, we propose a knowledge model that can be used to express both declarative knowledge about the systems' components, their relations and their current state, as well as procedural knowledge representing possible system behavior. In addition, we introduce a framework for knowledge management and automated reasoning (KMARF). The idea behind KMARF is to automatically select an appropriate problem solver based on formalized reasoning expertise in the knowledge base, and convert a problem definition to the corresponding format. This approach automates reasoning, thus reducing operational costs, and enables reusability of knowledge and methods across different domains. We illustrate the approach on a transportation planning use case.

sections.heading: 3 TAXONOMY OF ITS DOMAIN CONCEPTS
sections.text: This section describes the objects or concepts of the ITS domain and their relationship to more general CPS domain concepts, while the concepts are organized in an ontology that has multiple levels of abstraction. We design our ontology by combining top-level concepts and cross-domain relationships borrowed from three domains: CPS; agent-based model (ABM) and Systems-of-Systems (SoS). The proposed ontology consists of an upper ontology that includes the concepts and relationships of the CPS, ABM and SoS, as well as a general ITS domain ontology. sections.heading: 7 CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we have outlined concepts and strategies for creating a model for presenting knowledge from CPS and ITS domains in a machine-readable form, as well as KMARF, a generic framework for knowledge management and automated reasoning that integrates this knowledge model. The motivation behind creating a generating traffic planner and KMARF is to show that knowledge and methods can be reused in various areas to reduce the costs of developing, deploying and operating such systems. We have illustrated the use of parts of KMARF to generate traffic planning that can be used to quickly design shift plans for vehicle fleets.
